abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, and the institutional development
            impact substantial. The Bank's performance was
            satisfactory, while, the Borrower's performance was
            highly satisfactory given its consistent, effective efforts
            in the fulfillment, ownership, and operation of the project.
            Regardless of success, the nature of the rapidly developing
            economy, produced the competition faced by traditional
            wholesale markets vs. the development of contemporary
            private marketing infrastructure, namely supermarkets, and
            discount wholesale sellers, a factor not foreseen at project
            preparation, and which has narrowed the window of
            opportunity for traditional wholesale market structures.
            This has added an urgent need to find additional sources of
            revenue for the market, considering that revenues of
            traditional wholesale markets (particularly limited to trade
            in perishable agriculture products), are insufficient to
            support investments. Thus, traditional wholesale markets are
            justified as providers of public services, whose investment
            is a sunk cost incurred by society; yet, in light of modern
            trading venues, this justification may not hold long.
            Therefore, the economic, and financial justification would
            be to broaden the market concept of traditional wholesale
            trade in perishables, to a multi service establishment in
            wholesale food trade. The project exemplifies this proactive
            approach of management, and provides grounds for cautious
            optimism for the future.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Wholesale Markets Project for
            Poland aims to construct a commercially self-sustaining
            urban wholesale market for the greater Lublin area, complete
            with associated physical infrastructure. This project 1)
            builds a multi-purpose fresh produce trading hall, a dry
            goods market, a hall to sell flowers and pot plants with
            multiple buyer walks, semi-wholesalers/retailers booths for
            smaller traders, a market administration office complex
            enclosing an environmental health laboratory, broker's
            offices, a bank, a restaurant, workshops, and first
            aid/welfare facilities as well as ancillary facilities; 2)
            establishes medium to large wholesaler's units in a
            garage-type structure, an open farmers' market, on-site
            infrastructure including on-site earthworks and site
            preparation works, roads and circulation areas, road signs,
            pavements and ramps, decorative plants, boundary-fencing and
            gates, a water distribution/fire hydrant system, a water
            drainage system, an electric supply network, a gravity
            sewage system, and a communications system; 3) implements
            environmental mitigation measures; and 4) provides
            pre-startup expenses and covers interest and financial charges.
